author: new testament

0.0:
Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God,
according to the promise of the life which is in Christ Jesus,
0.1:
to Timothy, my beloved child: Grace, mercy, and peace, from God the Father
and Christ Jesus our Lord.
0.2:
I thank God, whom I serve as my forefathers did, with a pure
conscience. How unceasing is my memory of you in my petitions, night
and day
0.3:
longing to see you, remembering your tears, that I may be
filled with joy;
0.4:
having been reminded of the unfeigned faith that
is in you; which lived first in your grandmother Lois, and your mother
Eunice, and, I am persuaded, in you also.
0.5:
For this cause, I remind you that you should stir up the gift
of God which is in you through the laying on of my hands.
0.6:
For God
didn't give us a spirit of fear, but of power, love, and self-control.
0.7:
Therefore don't be ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of
me his prisoner; but endure hardship for the gospel according to the
power of God,
0.8:
who saved us and called us with a holy calling, not
according to our works, but according to his own purpose and grace,
which was given to us in Christ Jesus before times eternal,
0.9:
but
has now been revealed by the appearing of our Savior, Christ Jesus, who
abolished death, and brought life and immortality to light through the
gospel.
0.10:
For this, I was appointed as a preacher, an apostle, and
a teacher of the Gentiles.
0.11:
For this cause I suffer also these
things.

 Yet I am not ashamed, for I know him whom I have believed, and I am
persuaded that he is able to guard that which I have committed to him
against that day.
0.12:
Hold the pattern of sound words which you have heard from me,
in faith and love which is in Christ Jesus.
0.13:
That good thing
which was committed to you, guard through the Holy Spirit who dwells in
us.
0.14:
This you know, that all who are in Asia turned away from me;
of whom are Phygelus and Hermogenes.
0.15:
May the Lord grant mercy to
the house of Onesiphorus, for he often refreshed me, and was not
ashamed of my chain,
0.16:
but when he was in Rome, he sought me
diligently, and found me
0.17:
(the Lord grant to him to find the
Lord's mercy in that day); and in how many things he served at Ephesus,
you know very well.

1.0:
You therefore, my child, be strengthened in the grace that is
in Christ Jesus.
1.1:
The things which you have heard from me among
many witnesses, commit the same to faithful men, who will be able to
teach others also.
1.2:
You therefore must endure hardship, as a good
soldier of Christ Jesus.
1.3:
No soldier on service entangles himself
in the affairs of life, that he may please him who enrolled him as a
soldier.
1.4:
Also, if anyone competes in athletics, he isn't crowned
unless he has competed by the rules.
1.5:
The farmers who labor must
be the first to get a share of the crops.
1.6:
Consider what I say,
and may the Lord give you understanding in all things.
1.7:
Remember Jesus Christ, risen from the dead, of the seed of
David, according to my gospel,
1.8:
in which I suffer hardship to the
point of chains as a criminal. But God's word isn't chained.
1.9:
Therefore I endure all things for the elect's sake, that they also may
obtain the salvation which is in Christ Jesus with eternal glory.
1.10:
This saying is faithful:
For if we died with him,
 We will also live with him.
1.11:
If we endure,
 We will also reign with him.
If we deny him,
 He also will deny us.
1.12:
If we are faithless,
 He remains faithful. He can't deny himself.
1.13:
Remind them of these things, charging them in the sight of
the Lord, that they don't argue about words, to no profit, to the
subverting of those who hear.
1.14:
Give diligence to present yourself approved by God, a workman
who doesn't need to be ashamed, properly handling the Word of Truth.
1.15:
But shun empty chatter, for they will proceed further in
ungodliness,
1.16:
and their word will consume like gangrene, of whom
is Hymenaeus and Philetus;
1.17:
men who have erred concerning the
truth, saying that the resurrection is already past, and overthrowing
the faith of some.
1.18:
However God's firm foundation stands, having
this seal, "The Lord knows those who are his," and, "Let every one who
names the name of the Lord depart from unrighteousness."
1.19:
Now in
a great house there are not only vessels of gold and of silver, but
also of wood and of clay. Some are for honor, and some for dishonor.
1.20:
If anyone therefore purges himself from these, he will be a
vessel for honor, sanctified, and suitable for the master's use,
prepared for every good work.
1.21:
Flee from youthful lusts; but pursue righteousness, faith,
love, and peace with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart.
1.22:
But refuse foolish and ignorant questionings, knowing that they
generate strife.
1.23:
The Lord's servant must not quarrel, but be
gentle towards all, able to teach, patient,
1.24:
in gentleness
correcting those who oppose him: perhaps God may give them repentance
leading to a full knowledge of the truth,
1.25:
and they may recover
themselves out of the devil's snare, having been taken captive by him
to his will.

2.0:
But know this, that in the last days, grievous times will
come.
2.1:
For men will be lovers of self, lovers of money, boastful,
arrogant, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy,
2.2:
without natural affection, unforgiving, slanderers, without
self-control, fierce, no lovers of good,
2.3:
traitors, headstrong,
conceited, lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God;
2.4:
holding
a form of godliness, but having denied the power thereof. Turn away
from these, also.
2.5:
For of these are those who creep into houses,
and take captive gullible women loaded down with sins, led away by
various lusts,
2.6:
always learning, and never able to come to the
knowledge of the truth.
2.7:
Even as Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses,
so do these also oppose the truth; men corrupted in mind, reprobate
concerning the faith.
2.8:
But they will proceed no further. For their
folly will be evident to all men, as theirs also came to be.
2.9:
But
you did follow my teaching, conduct, purpose, faith, patience, love,
steadfastness,
2.10:
persecutions, and sufferings: those things that
happened to me at Antioch, Iconium, and Lystra. I endured those
persecutions. Out of them all the Lord delivered me.
2.11:
Yes, and
all who desire to live godly in Christ Jesus will suffer persecution.
2.12:
But evil men and impostors will grow worse and worse, deceiving
and being deceived.
2.13:
But you remain in the things which you have
learned and have been assured of, knowing from whom you have learned
them.
2.14:
From infancy, you have known the sacred writings which are
able to make you wise for salvation through faith, which is in Christ
Jesus.
2.15:
Every writing inspired by God is profitable for teaching,
for reproof, for correction, and for instruction which is in
righteousness,
2.16:
that the man of God may be complete, thoroughly
equipped for every good work.

3.0:
I charge you therefore before God and the Lord Jesus Christ,
who will judge the living and the dead at His appearing and His
kingdom:
3.1:
preach the word; be urgent in season and out of season;
reprove, rebuke, and exhort, with all patience and teaching.
3.2:
For
the time will come when they will not listen to the sound doctrine,
but, having itching ears, will heap up for themselves teachers after
their own lusts;
3.3:
and will turn away their ears from the truth,
and turn aside to fables.
3.4:
But you be sober in all things, suffer
hardship, do the work of an evangelist, and fulfill your ministry.
3.5:
For I am already being offered, and the time of my departure
has come.
3.6:
I have fought the good fight. I have finished the
course. I have kept the faith.
3.7:
From now on, there is stored up
for me the crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous judge,
will give to me on that day; and not to me only, but also to all those
who have loved his appearing.
3.8: Be diligent to come to me soon,
3.9:
for Demas left me, having loved this present world, and went to
Thessalonica; Crescens to Galatia, and Titus to Dalmatia.
3.10:
Only
Luke is with me. Take Mark, and bring him with you, for he is useful to
me for ministering.
3.11: But I sent Tychicus to Ephesus.
3.12:
Bring
the cloak that I left at Troas with Carpus when you come, and the
books, especially the parchments.
3.13:
Alexander, the coppersmith,
did much evil to me. The Lord will repay him according to his works,
3.14: of whom you also must beware; for he greatly opposed our words.
3.15:
At my first defense, no one came to help me, but all left me.
May it not be held against them.
3.16:
But the Lord stood by me, and
strengthened me, that through me the message might be fully proclaimed,
and that all the Gentiles might hear; and I was delivered out of the
mouth of the lion.
3.17:
And the Lord will deliver me from every evil
work, and will preserve me for his heavenly kingdom; to whom be the
glory forever and ever. Amen.
3.18: Greet Prisca and Aquila, and the house of Onesiphorus.
3.19: Erastus remained at Corinth, but I left Trophimus at Miletus sick.
3.20:
Be diligent to come before winter. Eubulus salutes you, as do
Pudens, Linus, Claudia, and all the brothers.
3.21:
The Lord Jesus
Christ be with your spirit. Grace be with you. Amen.
